awd_titl_txt: IIBR Informatics: Intuitive Sampling, Tracking and Counting Software for Biological Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
From studies of single cells to investigations of large organisms, many biologists study digital imagery to understand how life interacts with the environment. As biological research becomes more dependent on technology, the need for rapid analysis of digital data grows. Unfortunately, the software needed for many analyses is either prohibitively expensive or requires substantial training. This project will generate image analysis software that will allow biologists to easily perform measurements on digital photographs. The software generated will have an intuitive user interface with built-in instructions developed by biologists, it will contain a wide range of analysis tools that will allow users to determine the position, distance, area, angles, and colors on selected objects, and it will be freely available. A second facet of this project involves the creation of sophisticated tracking and motion analysis software. By providing these digital analysis tools for a broad population of biologists this project will advance research and education from top-tier institutions to high school laboratories.

The software will automate most repetitive tasks and provide common calculations from within so that data can be quickly extracted. In the tracking programs these calculations include static parameters, such as count, position, and size, and kinematic parameters, such as velocity and acceleration. Additionally, new tracking algorithms will be developed that utilize a variety of segmentation techniques to resolve overlapping objects and improve object identification. A newly devised morphed segmentation technique will be tested and implemented. This technique has the potential to generate more accurate counting and tracking of complex objects, such as animals in flight. The algorithm will use stored images from frames where the animals are moving individually. Then, when overlaps occur, individual animals will be approximated based on the stored images. The software developed here will be principally tested on data from research on the flight behavior of bats in groups. The results from this research will provide key data to understand the rules governing guidance behavior and collision avoidance in bats. Additionally, this project will involve two supplemental collaborations with investigators researching biology on the microscopic scale. Together, these collaborations will motivate refinements to the software so that it is suitable to meet the diverse needs of biological research. The goal of this project is to develop image and video analysis programs that can become the go-to free image analysis software for biologists. The software produced by this work can be found at: https://sourceforge.net/projects/scientific-image-analysis/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this research was to develop and test free user-friendly software. This software allows for simple image measurements to be made, and for tracking and counting of objects moving in videos. This software has been designed to be widely accessible and it can be used by researchers, students, and the general public. The resulting application has been called the Scientific Image Analysis (SIA) application and it can be downloaded from SourceForge at (Scientific Image Analysis download | SourceForge.net). The goal with SIA was to provide an intuitive user interface and when needed instructions are provided within the application interface. After downloading the SIA app, the different measurement types are displayed, and users can choose which type of measurement they would like to make, and the corresponding interface will appear.

In the process of testing this software some auxiliary results occurred. We have published scientific findings using both the image sampling aspect and the video counting. Specific tools in SIA that have been used are the length, angle measurement, and the counting tools. These have been used to further our scientific understanding of bird beak lengths and their relationship with environmental factors and to provide more accurate counts of bats in various caves which are of interest to conservation efforts.

We also determined that there was a sufficient user demand for the tracking and counting aspect for it to be created as a stand-alone application. This resulted in BatCount, which can also be downloaded from SourceForge at (BatCount download | SourceForge.net). The software was so named because it has been used primarily by a community of bat researchers and conservationists.

We have also used this research to begin to address one of the issues using the tracking and counting software which is when objects (bats, birds, or so on) move into or out of a region of interest they are counted, but if they are close to one another (from the perspective of the camera) then they may appear to be one object. We have prototyped a neural network algorithm which can provide more accurate counts of bats when they overlap. This feature has not been incorporated into the tracking and counting software (or the standalone BatCount) but it may be implemented in a future update to the software.
